_**Cha siu**_ ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language "Chinese language"): 叉燒;
[Cantonese Yale](/wiki/Yale_romanization_of_Cantonese "Yale romanization of
Cantonese"): _chāsīu_) is a popular way to flavor and prepare
[barbecued](/wiki/Barbecue "Barbecue") [pork](/wiki/Pork "Pork") in [Cantonese
cuisine](/wiki/Cantonese_cuisine "Cantonese cuisine").[1] It is classified as
a type of _[siu mei](/wiki/Siu_mei "Siu mei")_ (燒味), Cantonese roasted meat.

## Contents

  * 1 Meat cuts
  * 2 Chinese cuisine
  * 3 Hong Kong cuisine
  * 4 Southeast Asian cuisine
  * 5 Japanese cuisine
  * 6 Pacific Rim cuisine
  * 7 See also
  * 8 References

## Meat cuts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Char_siu&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Meat cuts")]

Pork cuts used for _cha siu_ can vary, but a few main cuts are common:[2]

  * [Pork loin](/wiki/Pork_loin "Pork loin")
  * [Pork belly](/wiki/Pork_belly "Pork belly") \- produces juicy and fatter _cha siu_
  * [Pork butt](/wiki/Pork_butt "Pork butt") (shoulder) - produces leaner _cha siu_
  * [Pork fat](/wiki/Fatback "Fatback")
  * Pork neck end - very marbled (_jyu geng yuk_)

## Chinese cuisine[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Char_siu&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Chinese cuisine")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/HK_Mongkok_Maxims_BBQ_Meat_Rice_Lunch_with_Green_vegetable.JPG/220px-
HK_Mongkok_Maxims_BBQ_Meat_Rice_Lunch_with_Green_vegetable.JPG)](/wiki/File:HK_Mongkok_Maxims_BBQ_Meat_Rice_Lunch_with_Green_vegetable.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:HK_Mongkok_Maxims_BBQ_Meat_Rice_Lunch_with_Green_vegetable.JPG
"Enlarge")

A plate of _cha siu_ rice

_Cha siu_ literally means "fork roasted" (_siu_ being burn/roast and _cha_
being fork, both noun and verb) after the traditional cooking method for the
dish: long strips of seasoned boneless pork are skewered with long forks and
placed in a covered oven or over a fire[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_].

In ancient times, wild boar and other available meats were used to make _cha
siu_. However, in modern times, the meat is typically a shoulder cut of
domestic pork, seasoned with a mixture of [honey](/wiki/Honey "Honey"), [five-
spice powder](/wiki/Five-spice_powder "Five-spice powder"), [red fermented
bean curd](/wiki/Fermented_bean_curd#Varieties "Fermented bean curd"), [dark
soy sauce](/wiki/Soy_sauce#Types "Soy sauce"), [hoisin
sauce](/wiki/Hoisin_sauce "Hoisin sauce"), red [food
colouring](/wiki/Food_colouring "Food colouring") (not a traditional
ingredient but very common in today's preparations and is optional), and
[sherry](/wiki/Sherry "Sherry") or [rice wine](/wiki/Huangjiu "Huangjiu")
(optional). These seasonings turn the exterior layer of the meat dark red,
similar to the "smoke ring" of American barbecues. [Maltose](/wiki/Maltose
"Maltose") may be used to give cha siu its characteristic shiny glaze.

_Cha siu_ is typically consumed with a staple, whether inside a bun (_[chasiu
baau](/wiki/Cha_siu_bao "Cha siu bao")_ , 叉燒包), with noodles (_chasiu min_ ,
叉燒麵), or with rice (_chasiu faan_ , 叉燒飯) in fast food establishments, or
served alone as a centerpiece or main dish in traditional family dining
establishments. If it is purchased outside of a restaurant, it is usually
taken home and used as one ingredient in various complex entrees consumed at
family meals.

## Hong Kong cuisine[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Char_siu&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Hong Kong cuisine")]

In [Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong"), _cha siu_ is usually purchased
from a _[siu mei](/wiki/Siu_mei "Siu mei")_ establishment, which specializes
in meat dishes— _cha siu_ pork, [soy sauce chicken](/wiki/Soy_sauce_chicken
"Soy sauce chicken"), [white cut chicken](/wiki/White_cut_chicken "White cut
chicken"), [roasted goose](/wiki/Roasted_goose "Roasted goose"), [roasted
pork](/wiki/Siu_yuk "Siu yuk"), etc. These shops usually display the
merchandise by hanging them in the window. As a result, _cha siu_ is often
consumed alongside one of these other meat dishes when eaten as an independent
lunch item on a per-person basis in a "rice box" meal. More commonly it is
purchased whole or sliced and wrapped and taken home to be used in family
meals either by itself or cooked into one of many vegetable or meat dishes
which use _cha siu_ pork as an ingredient.

## Southeast Asian
cuisine[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Char_siu&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Southeast Asian cuisine")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Bami_mu_daeng_kiao.JPG/220px-
Bami_mu_daeng_kiao.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bami_mu_daeng_kiao.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Bami_mu_daeng_kiao.JPG "Enlarge")

_Cha siu_ is often served in a noodle soup as here in [Chiang
Mai](/wiki/Chiang_Mai "Chiang Mai"), [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand "Thailand")

In [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia "Malaysia"), [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore
"Singapore"), Indonesia, and [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand "Thailand"), _cha siew_
rice is found in many Chinese _shāolà_ (烧腊) stalls along with roast duck and
roast pork. The dish consists of slices of _cha siu_ ,
[cucumbers](/wiki/Cucumbers "Cucumbers"), white rice and is drenched in sweet
gravy or drizzled with dark [soy sauce](/wiki/Soy_sauce "Soy sauce"). _Cha
siu_ rice is also a popular food within the Chinese community in
[Medan](/wiki/Medan "Medan"), [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia"), where
it is more called _cha sio_. _Cha siew_ rice can also be found in [Hainanese
chicken rice](/wiki/Hainanese_chicken_rice "Hainanese chicken rice") stalls,
where customers have a choice of having their _cha siu_ rice served with plain
white rice or chicken-flavoured rice, and choose from garlic, chilli and soy
sauces. _Cha siu_ is called _mu daeng_ ([Thai](/wiki/Thai_language "Thai
language"): หมูแดง, pronounced [[mǔː dɛ̄ːŋ]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Thai_and_Lao
"Help:IPA/Thai and Lao"), "red pork") in Thailand.

In the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"), it is known as Chinese
_[Asado](/wiki/Asado "Asado")_ and usually eaten with cold cuts or served
stuffed in _[siopao](/wiki/Siopao "Siopao")_. In Flanders and Holland it's
known by the Indonesian name 'babi panggang'.

Vegetarian _cha siu_ also exists, usually made from wheat gluten. It can be
found in vegetarian restaurants and stalls in South East Asian Chinese
communities.

## Japanese cuisine[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Char_siu&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Japanese cuisine")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/BBQ_Pork_Ramen.jpg/220px-
BBQ_Pork_Ramen.jpg)](/wiki/File:BBQ_Pork_Ramen.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:BBQ_Pork_Ramen.jpg "Enlarge")

_Chāshū_ ramen

Japanese culture has adapted 叉燒 as _chāshū_ (チャーシュー). Unlike its Chinese
variant, it is prepared by rolling the meat into a log and then braising it at
a low temperature. The Japanese adaptation is typically seasoned with honey
and soy sauce, without the red food colouring, sugar, or [five-spice
powder](/wiki/Five-spice_powder "Five-spice powder"). It is a typical
ingredient in _[rāmen](/wiki/Ramen "Ramen")_.

## Pacific Rim
cuisine[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Char_siu&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Pacific Rim cuisine")]

As a means of exceptional flavor and preparation, _cha siu_ applications
extend far beyond pork. In [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii"), various meats are
cooked _cha siu_ style. The term _cha siu_ refers to meats which have been
marinated in _cha siu_ seasoning prepared either from scratch or from store-
bought _cha siu_ seasoning packages, then roasted in an oven or over a fire.
Ingredients in marinades for _cha siu_ are similar to those found in China
(honey, five-spice, wine, soy, hoisin, etc.), except that red food coloring is
often used in place of the red bean curd for convenience. _Cha siu_ is used to
marinate and prepare a variety of meats which can either be cooked in a
conventional or convection oven (often not requiring the use of a fork or
_cha(zi)_ as traditional Chinese ovens do), on a standard barbecue, or even in
an underground Hawaiian _[imu](/wiki/Imu "Imu")_. In Hawaii, _cha siu_ chicken
is as common as _cha siu_ pork, and various wild birds, mountain goat, and
wild boar are also often cooked _cha siu_ style, as are many sausages and
skewers.

As _cha siu_ grows in popularity, innovative chefs from around the world,
especially chefs from around the Pacific Rim, from Australia to California,
are using various meats prepared _cha siu_ style in their cuisines and
culinary creations.
